H0.text: High altitude above sea level causes the alpine tundra to be so cold.

H1.text: Moderate altitude causes the alpine tundra to be so cold.

H2.text: Low altitude causes the alpine tundra to be so cold.

H3.text: Low air density at high elevations causes the alpine tundra to be so cold.

A4.text: The high elevation causes an adverse climate, which is too cold and windy to support tree growth.

A5.text: The cold climate of the alpine tundra is caused by adiabatic cooling of air, and is similar to polar climate.

A6.text: The rate of decrease of temperature with elevation is known as the adiabatic lapse rate, which is approximately 9.8 °C per kilometer (or 5.4 °F per 1000 feet) of altitude.

A7.text: High altitude is sometimes defined to begin at 2,400 meters (8,000 ft) above sea level, where atmospheric pressure is lower than that at sea level.
